column4: can I ask pc hardware related questions here, or is it strictly ubuntu only?
people here know a lot about hardware too, I'm sure, go ahead and ask
Windows has limitations for sure, but I don't know of any other limitations simply based on hardware.

I would be surprised if it had limitations, I am pretty sure, IDE is IDE, and SATA is SATA, regardless of size, therefore if a motherboard supports the standard, it should be able to support any size of HDD using that standard.
FAT32 does have limitations, I believe, I don't know what they are right off hand, but I am pretty sure there is some sort of size constraint on that FS
but if you are running an ubuntu server which is probably using an ext3 filesystem, why would you want to use FAT32 instead of ext3?
You might just want to go with NTFS, FAT32 support is slow even on windows
is right, but I don't want to pay for a windows licence
you should just try NTFS then
I don't (publicly) condone piracy, but who says you have to pay for anything these days? lol
if you are going the route of APACHE then the filesystem won't matter because it will all be done over HTTP
and samba is a good choice too, since it facilitates the sharing of files between linux and windows computers
well since your computer would BE the server, there would be no uploading process, things would just be available from the network.
well either way, putting things on the server would make them availiable to the network if you have the permissions set up that way.
you should go for samba in that case
it's not bad, but it does take work, just like most things on linux...
it's configured through a config file somewhere. I don't mean to be blunt, but you should stop asking about it and go play with it. It's free and you have nothing to lose.
